review.translation[0].definitions[0].def: a careful examination of a situation or process
review.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: The policy comes up for review (=will be reviewed) in April.
All fees are subject to review (=may be reviewed).
Mr Crowther asked for judicial review of the decision  (=an examination of the decision by a judge).
The company hired Bob to conduct an independent review of their workplace procedures.
She sent us her review of the research.
We’re keeping this policy under review  (=we are continuing to examine it).
review.translation[0].definitions[1].def: an article in a newspaper or magazine that gives an opinion about a new book, play, film etc
review.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: The film opened to rave reviews (=reviews that praised it a lot).
The band’s new album has had very good reviews.
The paper published a review of her book.
review.translation[0].definitions[2].def: the work of writing reviews for a newspaper or magazine
review.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: The journal receives review copies (=free copies to review) of most new software products.
The book was sent to the press for review in September.
review.translation[0].definitions[3].def: a report on a series of events or a period of time, that mentions the most important parts
review.translation[0].definitions[4].def: an official show of the army, navy etc so that a king, president, or officer of high rank can see them
review.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: No one has yet carried out a review of the system.
Government officials are conducting a review of the law.
The department plans to undertake a spending review.
He recommended that the matter should be kept under review.
His contract is coming up for review.
These prices are subject to review.
We are conducting a major review of our procedures.
Their conclusion is based on a comprehensive review of all the previous studies.
He is currently conducting a wide-ranging review of public spending.
There have been calls for a fundamental review of our voting system.
There will be an annual review of your salary.
Their findings have been confirmed by a recent independent review.
The Army is conducting an internal review.
The case is likely to go to judicial review.
The policy review proposed radical changes to the system.
Extra money was promised in last summer’s spending review.
We will set up a pay review body for all staff.
We cannot comment until the review process is over.
review.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to examine, consider, and judge a situation or process carefully in order to see if changes are necessary
review.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: We will review your situation and decide how we can help you.
The decision will be reviewed by the Supreme Court.
The team manager’s position will be reviewed at the end of the season.
review.translation[1].definitions[1].def: to write a short article describing and judging a new book, play, film etc
review.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: Bradman will review the best of the new children’s books.
review.translation[1].definitions[2].def: to look again at something you have studied, such as notes, reports etc
review.translation[1].definitions[3].def: to examine and describe the most important parts of a series of events or period of time
review.translation[1].definitions[3].exa: a journalist who will review the events of the past six months
review.translation[1].definitions[4].def: to officially watch a group of soldiers, ships etc at a military show
review.translation[1].definitions[4].exa: The president will review the soldiers on parade.
review.translation[2].definitions[0].def: when a situation or process is examined and considered carefully to see if it can be improved
review.translation[2].definitions[0].exa: The company is conducting an internal review (=done by employees of the company) of its activities.
The plant is still under review for possible closure.
review.translation[2].definitions[1].def: when a RATINGS AGENCY examines particular bonds, debts etc to see if there has been a change in the level of risk that they will not be repaid
review.translation[2].definitions[1].exa: Moody’s has placed $2.5 billion of the company’s debt under review for possible upgrading.
review.translation[2].definitions[2].def: an article in a newspaper or magazine that gives an opinion about a new restaurant, product, film etc
review.translation[2].definitions[2].exa: Despite good reviews from food critics, the restaurant hasn’t made a profit in two years.
review.translation[3].definitions[0].def: to examine or consider a situation or process carefully to see if it can be improved
review.translation[3].definitions[0].exa: We hired an outside consultant to review our pricing policies.
The situation is being reviewed on a day-to-day basis.
review.translation[3].definitions[1].def: to examine particular bonds, debt etc to see if there has been a change in the level of risk that they will not be repaid
review.translation[3].definitions[1].exa: The company’s debt is being reviewed by Moody’s for possible downgrading.
review.translation[3].definitions[2].def: to write an article saying how good you think a new restaurant, product, film etc is
review.translation[3].definitions[2].exa: He reviews new models for a car magazine.
review.translation[3].definitions[3].def: to look at a document such as a report in detail
review.translation[3].definitions[3].exa: I need more time to review your report.
